Design and evaluation of components that are critical to artificial intelligence (AI) driven control systems, including but not limited to sensor fusion, feature engineering, computer vision (semantic segmentation, objection detection), ML based classification, and learning-based control systems. Team project including a final presentation and report.

title: Applied Machine Learning Senior Design Projects
description: Design, development, and evaluation of components that are critical to artificial intelligence (AI) driven control systems. Team project including a final presentation and report. Example design themes include but not limited to self-driving cars, smart healthcare, and precision agriculture.

title: Internet of Things
description: Introduction to principles, technologies, challenges, and required expertise to build the Internet of Things (IoT) solutions. Sensing, computing, wireless communication, IP communication, and cloud processing for building an IoT solution.

title: Internet of Things Senior Design Project
description: Propose and design a senior IoT design project, using the design principles they have studied in the prerequisite course, Internet of Things.

title: Applied Machine Learning for Electrical & Computer Engineers
description: Fundamental techniques in machine learning for data preparation, preprocessing, classification, and regression. Bringing practical machine learning algorithms to the field and deploying them on real problems in hardware, mobile health, embedded systems, security, and other related topics.

title: Digital Systems II
description: Computer-aided design of digital systems with emphasis on hardware description languages (VHDL), logic synthesis, and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGA). May cover advanced topics in digital system design such as static timing analysis, pipelining, memory system design, testing digital circuits.

title: Digital Systems Design Project
description: Digital-system and computer-engineering design course involving architecture, design, implementation and testing of a prototype application-specific processor under given design constraints. Team project includes a final presentation and report.

title: Digital Systems Design Project
description: Digital-system and computer-engineering design course involving architecture, design, implementation and testing of a prototype application-specific processor under given design constraints. Team project includes a final presentation and report.

title: Testing & Verification of Digital Systems
description: Computer aided-testing and design verification techniques for digital systems; physical fault testing; simulation-based design verification; formal verification; timing analysis.

description: Special topics in Computer Science.

description: Special topics in Programming Systems.

title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Opto-Electronics
description: Special topics in Opto-Electronics.

title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Computer Networks
description: Special topics in Computer Networks.

title: Research Group Conferences in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Research group conferences.

title: Internship in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Supervised work experience in electrical and computer engineering.

title: Senior Design Project
description: Team design project for seniors in Electrical or Computer Engineering. Project involves analysis, design, implementation and evaluation of an Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering system. Project is supervised by a faculty member.

title: Senior Design Project
description: Team design project for seniors in Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering. Project involves analysis, design, implementation and evaluation of an Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering system. Project supervised by a faculty member.

title: Autonomous Vehicle Design Project
description: Design and construct an autonomous race car. Work in groups to design, build and test speed control circuits, track sensing circuits, and a steering control loop.

title: Autonomous Vehicle Design Project
description: Design and construct an autonomous race car. Students work in groups to design, build and test speed control circuits, track sensing circuits, and a steering control loop.

title: Issues in Engineering Design
description: Covers various electrical and computer engineering standards and realistic design constraints including economic, manufacturability, sustainability, ethical, health & safety, environmental, social, and political.

title: Tutoring in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Tutoring in Electrical & Computer Engineering courses, especially introductory circuits. For upper division undergraduate students who will provide tutorial assistance.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

title: Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

title: Navigating Graduate School
description: Practical and non-technical skills necessary for first-year students in the Electrical & Computer Engineering Graduate Group. Mentorship, time management, research ethics, science communication, intellectual property.

title: Digital Signal Processing
description: Theory and design of digital filters. Classification of digital filters, linear phase systems, all-pass functions, FIR and IIR filter design methods and optimality measures, numerically robust structures for digital filters.

title: Computational Methods in Biomedical Imaging
description: Analytic tomographic reconstruction from projections in 2D and 3D; model-based image reconstruction methods; maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods; applications to CT, PET, and SPECT.

title: Digital Image Processing
description: Two-dimensional systems theory, image perception, sampling and quantization, transform theory and applications, enhancement, filtering and restoration, image analysis, and image processing systems.

title: MOS Analog Circuit Design
description: Analysis and design of MOS amplifiers, bias circuits, voltage references and other analog circuits. Stability and compensation of feedback amplifiers. Introduction to noise analysis in MOS circuits.

title: Advanced Analog Circuit Design
description: Noise and distortion in electronic circuits and systems. Application to communication circuits. Specific applications include mixers, low-noise amplifiers, power amplifiers, phase-locked loops, oscillators and receiver architectures.

title: Analog MOS IC Design for Signal Processing
description: Analysis and design of analog MOS integrated circuits. Passive components, Single-ended and fully differential op amps, Sampled-data and continuous-time filters.

title: Data-Conversion Techniques & Circuits
description: Digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion; component characteristics and matching; sample-and-hold, comparator, amplifier, and reference circuits.

title: Integrated Circuit Design for Power Electronics
description: IC design for power electronics. Linear and switching regulation. Integrated power management. DC/DC and AC/DC conversion. Applications in portable electronics and wireless sensors.

title: Circuits for Digital Communications
description: Analog, digital, and mixed-signal CMOS implementations of communication-circuit blocks: gain control, adaptive equalizers, sampling detectors, clock recovery.

title: Low Power Digital Integrated Circuit Design
description: Integrated circuit design for low power and energy consumption. Low power architectures, logic styles and circuit design. Variable supply and threshold voltages. Leakage management. Power estimation. Energy sources, power electronics, and energy recovery. Applications in portable electronics and sensors. Thermodynamic limits.

title: Radio Frequency & Microwave Filter Design
description: Design of radio frequency and microwave filters including filter specification and approximation theory. Passive LC filter design covers doubly-terminated reactance two-port synthesis and coupling matrix based synthesis. Active filter design includes sensitivity, op-amp building blocks, and cascade filter design.

title: RF IC Design
description: Radio frequency (RF) solid-state devices, RF device modeling and design rules; non-linear RF circuit design techniques; use of non-linear computer-aided (CAD) tools; RF power amplifier design.

title: RF Integrated Circuits for Wireless Communications
description: Integrated RF front end circuit design of receivers and synthesizers for wireless communications, such as LNA, mixers, PLL; noise and linearity analysis and specifications; theory and working mechanism of synthesizers and phase noise analysis.

title: Terahertz & mm-Wave Integrated Circuit Design
description: Fundamental theory of RF transmitter and receiver, including noise analysis, transceiver architectures, and antenna arrays. Fundamental limitations, theory and design of amplifiers, oscillators and signal sources at THz and mm-wave frequencies.

title: Advanced Microwave Circuit & Device Design Techniques
description: Theory, design, fabrication, analysis of advanced microwave circuits and devices. Wideband transformers, stripline/microstripline broadband couplers. Lumped and distributed filter synthesis. Broadband matching theory applied to microwave devices. Wideband and low noise FET/HEMT amplifiers. Advanced microwave oscillator theory. Phase noise analysis.

title: RF-MEMS & Adaptive Wireless Frontends
description: Focuses on the modeling, design, fabrication, and characterization of RF-MEMS while providing a thorough introduction to the technology with an emphasis on how it will benefit the design of adaptive RF/microwave wireless systems.

title: Electromagnetics
description: Maxwell's equations, plane waves, reflection and refraction, complex waves, waveguides, resonant cavities, and basic antennas.

title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion I
description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion II
description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion III
description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

title: Advanced Applied Electromagnetics I
description: The exact formulation of applied electromagnetic problems using Green's functions. Applications of these techniques to transmission circuits.

title: Advanced Applied Electromagnetics II
description: An advanced treatment of electromagnetics with applications to passive microwave devices and antennas.

title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices I
description: Physics & technology of electron beam emission, flow and transport, electron gun design, space charge waves & klystrons with applications to accelerator systems, RF power sources for radar & communication systems, thermionic energy conversion, and electric space propulsion. Recent advances in materials & manufacturing technologies are also reviewed.

title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices I
description: Physics & technology of electron beam emission, flow and transport, electron gun design, space charge waves & klystrons with applications to accelerator systems, RF power sources for radar & communication systems, thermionic energy conversion, and electric space propulsion. Recent advances in materials & manufacturing technologies also reviewed.

title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices II
description: Theory, modeling, & experimental design of traveling wave tubes, backward wave oscillators, and extended interaction oscillators employed in satellite commutations, plasma imaging, and underground imaging systems.

title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices II
description: Theory, modeling, & experimental design of traveling wave tubes, backward wave oscillators, and extended interaction oscillators employed in satellite commutations, plasma imaging, and underground imaging systems.

title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices III
description: Physics & technology of gyrotrons, gyro-amplifiers, free electron lasers, magnetrons, cross-field amplifiers, and relativistic devices employed in plasma fusion reactors, microwave heating, and high power microwave applications.

title: Physics and Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices III
description: Physics & technology of gyrotrons, gyro-amplifiers, free electron lasers, magnetrons, cross-field amplifiers, and relativistic devices employed in plasma fusion reactors, microwave heating, and high power microwave applications.

title: Photonics
description: Optical propagation of electromagnetic waves and beams in photonic components and the design of such devices using numerical techniques.

title: Nonlinear Optical Applications
description: Nonlinear optical interactions in optical communication, optical information processing and integrated optics. Basic concepts underlying optical nonlinear interactions in materials and guided media.

title: Lasers
description: Theoretical and practical description of lasers. Theory of population inversion, amplification and oscillation using semiclassical oscillator model and rate equations. Description and design of real laser system.

title: Laser Physics II
description: Oscillation threshold. Coupled cavity/atomic rate equations, Linear pulse propagation; dispersion, broadening, compression. Nonlinear pulse propagation. Energy extraction. Optical beams, resonators, eigenmodes, axial/transverse modes. Paraxial ray optics, resonator stability, ABCD matrices. Laser dynamics; transients, spiking, Q-switching, active and passive modelocking.

title: Semiconductor Lasers & Photonic Integration
description: Understanding of fundamental optical transitions in semiconductors and quantum-confined systems are applied to diode & unipolar lasers and selected photonic devices. The importance of radiative and non-radiative recombination, simulated emission, excitons in quantum wells, and strained quantum layers are considered. Photonic integrated circuits based on active (with optical gain) and passive (without optical gain).

title: Optical Communication Technologies  for High-Speed Data Networking
description: Enabling technologies for optical fiber communication and data center networks. Physical layer issues for component and system technologies in high-speed data optical communications. High-capacity data multiplexing technologies including wavelength-division-multiplexing, time-division-multiplexing, and advanced coherent modulation. Optical signal transmission, optical amplification, and optical switching for telecom and data center networks.

title: High-Capacity Optical Data Systems & Networks
description: High-capacity optical data systems and networks, built-on modern optical communication technologies. Technologies behind data center networking, software defined networking, and RF-optical networking. Physical layer issues in light of networking architectures and protocols. Optical communications systems design and integration. Systems technologies and higher-level network architecture, case studies. WDM, TDM, and EON networking, optical and wireless access technologies based on PON and ROF.

title: Semiconductor Device Physics
description: Physical principles, characteristics and models of various semiconductor materials and devices, including: P-N junction, metal- semiconductor diodes, junction, and insulated-gate field effect transistors.  Elements of basic design exercises to explore circuit design, RF phenomenon, optoelectronics, solid-state devices, materials, and large-scale integration.

title: Advanced Nanostructured Devices
description: Physics of nano-structured materials and device operation. Overview of new devices enabled by nanotechnology; fabrication and characterization methods; applications of nano-structures and devices.

title: Optical Imaging & Microscopy
description: Theory and techniques of optical imaging & microscopy. Fourier optics; light propagation & light detection; imaging contrast mechanisms; optical & microscopy techniques.

title: Introduction to Neuroengineering
description: Survey of neuroengineering field from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication technology; optical and electrical techniques to monitor and modulate neural activity; computational tools and control systems; prosthetics and human machine interfaces; human performance and rehabilitation; cognitive neuroengineering; neuroethics; extensive proposal development to merge aforementioned themes into a multidisciplinary project.

title: Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
description: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.

title: Advanced Projects in IC Fabrication
description: Individualized projects in the fabrication of analog or digital integrated electronic or optoelectronic circuits.

title: Photovoltaics & Solar Cells
description: Physics and application of photovoltaics and solar cells, including design, fabrication technology, and grid incorporation. Mono and microcrystalline silicon devices; thin-film technologies, heterojunction and organic-semiconductor technologies. Collectors, electrical inverters and infrastructure issues. Challenges and concerns.

title: Nanofabrication
description: Theory and practice of nanofabrication (top-down and bottom-up approaches), used for producing integrated circuits, electronic devices, sensors, and microstructures. Process development and characterization.

title: Linear Systems & Signals
description: Mathematical description of systems. Selected topics in linear algebra. Solution of the state equations and an analysis of stability, controllability, observability, realizations, state feedback and state estimation. Discrete-time signals and systems, and the Z-transform.

title: Nonlinear Systems
description: Nonlinear differential equations, second-order systems, approximation methods, bifurcations, Lyapunov stability, absolute stability, Popov criterion, circle criterion, sliding-mode control, feedback linearization techniques.

title: Multivariable Control System Design
description: Review of single-loop feedback design. Stability, performance and robustness of multi-input multi-output control systems. H-infinity design. Frequency response methods. Optimization-based design. Algebraic design methods for uncertain systems.

title: Optimization
description: Understanding, analyzing, and solving constrained convex optimization problems arising in cutting-edge engineering and science fields, including machine learning, signal processing, networks, control, transportation, and circuit design. Convexity theory and the algorithmic approaches for convex optimization problem.

title: Robotic Systems
description: Introduction to robotic systems. Mechanical manipulators, kinematics, manipulator positioning and path planning. Dynamics of manipulators. Robot motion programming and control algorithm design.

title: Reinforcement Learning
description: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is the subset of machine learning, the core of artificial intelligence. Topics include fundamentals of RL, bandit problems, Markov decision processes, and dynamic programming.

title: Random Signals & Noise
description: Random processes as probabilistic models for signals and noise. Probability and random variables, Convergence and limit theorems, Specification of random processes, Markov Chains, Wiener process and white Gaussian noise, Poisson process and shot noise, Processing and frequency analysis of random signals.

title: Signal Processing for Communications
description: Signal processing in wireless and wireline communication systems. Characterization and distortion of wireless and wireline channels. Channel equalization and maximum likelihood sequence estimation. Channel precoding and pre-equalization. OFDM and transmit diversity. Array processing.

title: Multi-access Communications Theory
description: Maximum stable throughput of Poisson collision channels. Classic collision resolution algorithms. Carrier sensing multiple access and its performance analysis. System stability analysis. Joint design of the physical/medium access control layers. Capacity region of multi-access channels. Multi-access with correlated sources.

title: Optimal & Adaptive Filtering
description: Geometric formulation of least-squares estimation problems. Theory and applications of optimum Wiener and Kalman filtering. MAP and maximum likelihood estimation of hidden Markov models, Viterbi algorithm. Adaptive filtering algorithms, properties and applications.

title: Estimation & Detection of Signals in Noise
description: Introduction to parameter estimation and detections of signals in noise. Bayes and Neyman-Pearson likelihood-ratio tests for signal detection. Maximum-likelihood parameter estimation. Detection of known and Gaussian signals in white or colored noise. Applications to communications, radar, signal processing.

title: Principles of Digital Communications
description: Introduction to digital communications. Coding for analog sources. Characterization of signals and systems. Modulation and demodulation for the additive Gaussian channel. Digital signaling over bandwidth-constrained linear filter channels and over fading multipath channels. Spread spectrum signals.

title: Information Theory & Coding
description: Topics include Entropy, Relatively Entropy, Mutual Information; Asymptotic Equipartition Property; Entropy Rates of Stochastic Process; Data Compression; Channel Capacity; Differential Entropy; Gaussian Channel; Rate Distortion Theory; Network Information Theory.

title: Mobile Communications
description: Time-varying multi-path fading channel models and receiver performance in fading channels; multiple access techniques and multiple access receivers design and performance; optimum design and the capacity of wireless channels.

title: Error Correcting Codes: Algebraic Approach
description: Introduction to theory and practice of block codes, linear block codes, cyclic codes, decoding algorithms, and coding techniques.

title: Error Correcting Codes: Probabilistic Approach
description: Probabilistic approach to construct and decode error-correcting codes, coded communication systems, low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes, polar codes, fountain codes, decoding algorithms.

title: Computer Architecture
description: Introduction to modern techniques for high-performance single and multiple processor systems. Topics include advanced pipeline design, advanced memory hierarchy design, optimizing pipeline and memory use, and memory sharing among multiprocessors. Case studies of recent single and multiple processor systems.

title: High-Performance Computer Architecture
description: Designing and analysis of high performance computer architecture with emphasis on vector processing, on-chip interconnect networks, chip-level multiprocessors, memory and storage subsystem design and impact of technological advances on computer architecture.

title: Networking Architecture & Resource Management
description: Design & implementation principles of networking architecture and protocols. Internet, data center, and telephony case studies. Topics: Internet data & control planes; application & services; resource management; Quality of Service (QoS) provisioning; traffic engineering; performance evaluation, software-defined networks, & future research issues.

title: Introduction to Hardware Security
description: Hardware Security. Cryptographic processing and the analysis of its overhead, physical attacks, side-channel attacks and counter measures, physically unclonable functions, hardware-based random number generators, watermarking of Intellectual Property blocks, field-programmable gate array security, printed circuit board security, passive and active metering for prevention of piracy, and access control.

title: Modern Parallel Computing
description: Exploration of the architecture of modern parallel computers, their programming models, and their programming systems.

title: VLSI Digital Signal Processing
description: Digital signal processors, building blocks, and algorithms. Design and implementation of processor algorithms, architectures, control, functional units, and circuit topologies for increased performance and reduced circuit size and power dissipation.

title: Advanced Design Verification of Digital Systems
description: Design verification techniques for digital systems; simulation-based design verification techniques; formal verification techniques, including equivalence checking, model checking, and theorem proving; timing analysis and verification; application of design cerification techniques to microprocessors.

title: Design & Optimization of Embedded Computing Systems
description: Introduction to design and optimization of digital computing systems for embedded applications. Topics include combinatorial optimization techniques, performance and energy optimization in embedded systems, compilation and architecture-specific mapping, programmable and reconfigurable platforms; design automation and algorithmic improvements to design process.

title: Introduction to Digital System Testing
description: Review of several current techniques used to detect physical faults in both combinational and sequential circuits. Topics include fault modeling, fault simulation, test generation, compression techniques, and testing architectures.

title: Seminar in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Discussion and presentation of current research and development in Electrical & Computer Engineering.

title: Graduate Research Group Conference in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Research problems, progress, and techniques in electrical and computer engineering.

title: Capstone Project For MS Plan II
description: Conducting research projects in electrical and computer engineering. Communicating research results in written reports and oral presentations. Systemic project implementation to answer a comprehensive scientific or technical question in the area of electrical and computer engineering.

title: Solid-State Circuit Research Laboratory Seminar
description: Lectures on solid-state circuit and system design by various visiting experts in the field.

title: Seminar in Solid-State Technology
description: Lectures on solid-state technology by various visiting experts in the field.

title: Computer Engineering Research Seminar
description: Lectures, tutorials and seminars on topics in computer engineering.

title: Communications, Signal & Image Processing Seminar
description: Communications, signal and image processing, video engineering and computer vision.

title: Systems, Control & Robotics Seminar
description: Seminars on current research in systems and control by faculty and visiting experts. Technical presentations and lectures on current topics in robotics research and robotics technology.

title: Photonics Research Seminar
description: Lectures on photonics and related areas by faculty and visiting experts.

title: Group Study
description: Group study.

title: Research
description: Research.

title: The Teaching of Electrical Engineering
description: Participation as a teaching assistant or associate-in in a designated engineering course. Methods of leading discussion groups or laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, use of laboratory equipment, and grading laboratory reports.

title: Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Teaching Assistant training.

title: Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
description: Intended to give the undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students will learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies, using examples from ongoing studies.

title: Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
description: Intended to give the upper division undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies.

title: Preceptorship in Emergency Medicine
description: Exposure to the specialty of Emergency Medicine and observation of a wide array of patients in the Emergency Department.

title: Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
description: First in a longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

title: Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
description: Second longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

title: Introduction to Medical Toxicology
description: In-depth review of clinical and medical toxicologic emergencies. Rotation includes contact with toxicology trained emergency faculty, didactic lectures, journal club, simulation training and exposure to a very busy poison control center.

title: Diagnostic Medicine for the Undifferentiated Patient
description: Distance Learning Didactic Elective. Develop skills for clinical assessment and diagnostic planning for common acute complaints. Develop a process for further expansion of clinical assessment skills that can be utilized for any chief complaint. Develop a broad differential diagnosis based solely on the chief complaint; “scripts” are created. Problem-based learning, self-study, and a diagnostic modality project is utilized.

title: Wilderness Medicine
description: Introductory elective course for students to explore how physicians can interact with the environment in austere conditions through lectures, hands-on/field experience, and case-based learning.

title: Emergency Medicine Clerkship
description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.

title: Emergency Medicine Ultrasound for Fourth-Year Medical Student
description: Intended for students interested in learning both the technical and cognitive skills of bedside ultrasound. Emphasis will be on the use of ultrasound in emergency medicine as a diagnostic tool and in procedural guidance.

title: Focus on POCUS A
description: Gain a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice, such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.

title: Focus on POCUS B
description: Directed towards gaining a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for those pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.

title: Externship in Emergency Medicine
description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.

title: Pediatric Emergency Medicine Clerkship
description: See patients in the Pediatric area of the Emergency Department under the supervision of an Emergency Medicine Attending. Emphasis on recognition and management of the acutely ill pediatric patient and treatment of common pediatric complaints.

title: Addiction Medicine; Advanced Clinical Clerkship
description: Consists primarily of clinical experiences, with complementary didactics. Clinical experiences will be multidisciplinary, working with drug and alcohol counselors, harm reduction workers, and physicians in family medicine, emergency medicine, internal medicine, and psychiatry. Clinical skills focus on risk factors, diagnosis, comorbidities, and treatment of substance use disorders.

title: Understanding Health Policy: A Focus on Analysis & Translation
description: Paradigm of healthcare delivery in the U.S. is changing rapidly. To prepare the next generation of physician leaders, provide the skills, tools, and knowledge needed to impact decisions made at the policy level.

title: Emergency Procedures Elective
description: Simulator-based skills training for emergency procedures. Topics include airway management, central venous access, chest tube placement, and general critical care resuscitation skills.

title: Research
description: Elective where topics may be selected in either basic or clinical research areas of Emergency and/or Critical Care Medicine. The goals will be tailored to each individual student. Enrollment requires prior discussion and consent of instructor.

title: Internship in Endocrinology
description: Supervised work experience in endocrinology.

title: Research
description: Endocrinology research.

title: Endocrinology Clinical Clerkship
description: Participation with members of subspecialty service in the initial evaluation, work-up, management and follow-up of patients with endocrinologic disorders.

title: Clinical Nutrition Clerkship
description: In-depth experience in assessment and monitoring of nutritional support of patients whose illnesses are complicated by malnutrition and of patients with problems in under-nutrition due to various illnesses.

title: Insights in Endocrinology
description: First- or second-year students observe in morning Endocrine and Diabetes clinics; attend bi-weekly noon and afternoon endocrine conferences. Present brief endocrine physiology oral presentation to the endocrine group.

title: Research
description: Research.

title: Introduction to Energy Systems
description: Technical, societal and environmental components of energy systems at global, national and regional scales from an interdisciplinary perspective. Energy resources; end-uses and demand; electricity systems; energy efficiency; energy justice; energy emissions; energy policy.

title: Life Cycle Assessment for Sustainable Engineering
description: Life cycle assessment methodology. Emphasis on applications to infrastructure and energy systems. Life cycle design, life cycle cost methods, other tools from industrial ecology, and links to policy.

title: Energy & Climate Policy
description: Fundamentals of energy technology, economics, and policy. Survey and analysis of current and prospective climate policies at the local and global level, including but not limited to cap-and-trade, emissions offsets, intensity standards, technology standards, mandates and subsidies.

title: Energy Seminar
description: Selected topics of current interest in energy. Topics vary and will be announced at the beginning of each quarter. Seminar speakers include invited speakers from outside the university as well as faculty.

title: Group Study
description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.

title: Group Study
description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.

title: Research
description: Research.

title: Introduction to Engineering
description: Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

title: Introduction to Engineering Design
description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.

title: Introduction to Engineering Design
description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills  integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.

title: Engineering Graphics in Design
description: Engineering design, descriptive geometry, pictorial sketching, computer-aided graphics, and their application in the solution of engineering problems.

title: Engineering Problem Solving
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Methodology for solving engineering problems. Engineering computing and visualization based on MATLAB. Engineering examples and applications.

title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
description: Students from all majors will learn the processes involved in modern entrepreneurship and identify an opportunity for innovation. The 3 C's of the entrepreneurial mindset (developed by KEEN) will be covered: Curiosity, Connections, and Creating Values.

title: Technology Startup Speaker Series
description: Presentations from successful entrepreneurs about the challenges of building a technology company, leadership, barriers faced by underrepresented founders, and professional resources to support student entrepreneurship.

title: The Science Behind the Technology in Our Lives
description: Understanding of how the technology in our lives works using only basic concepts and rudimentry mathematics.

title: Issues in Engineering
description: Engineering profession and its role in society; engineering design and development process; introduction to the engineering grand challenges; and professional resources for students.

title: Issues in Engineering
description: Engineering disciplines; the engineering profession’s methods, principles, and career opportunities; professional resources for students.

title: Circuits I
description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.

title: Circuits I
description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.

title: Introduction to Space Exploration: Understanding the Technological & Environmental Challenges
description: Introductory overview of the space environment. Discussion of space exploration technology including propulsion, orbital mechanics, and spacecraft engineering.

title: Statics
description: Force systems and equilibrium conditions with emphasis on engineering problems.

title: Properties of Materials
description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.

title: Honors Properties of Materials
description: Examination of special materials science and engineering topics through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.

title: Properties of Materials
description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

title: Electronic Circuits & Systems
description: Introduction to analog and digital circuit and system design through hands on laboratory design projects.

title: Dynamics
description: Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.

title: Fluid Mechanics
description: Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis and boundary-layer flows.

title: Mechanics of Materials
description: Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams. Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.

title: Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
description: Experiments which illustrate the basic principles and verify the analysis procedures used in the mechanics of materials are performed using the basic tools and techniques of experimental stress analysis.

title: Mechanics of Materials
description: Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams. Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.

title: Thermodynamics
description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics: heat energy and work, properties of pure substances, First and Second Law for closed and open systems, reversibility, entropy, thermodynamic temperature scales. Applications of thermodynamics to engineering systems. May be taught abroad.

title: Engineering Economics
description: Analysis of problems in engineering economy; the selection of alternatives; replacement decisions. Compounding, tax, origins and cost of capital, economic life, and risk and uncertainty are applied to methods of selecting most economic alternatives.

title: Launching a Company
description: Technological innovation and product development. Working as a team to turn ideas into companies through customer development.

title: Electric Machinery Fundamentals
description: Principles of AC and DC electric motors and generators, their control systems and power sources. Selection of electric power equipment components based on their construction features and performance characteristics.

title: Fluid Power Actuators & Systems
description: Hydraulic and pneumatic systems with emphasis on analysis and control of actuators. Design of hydraulic and pneumatic systems, specification and sizing of components, and selection of electro-hydraulics/electro-pneumatics, servo valves, and closed loop systems to solve basic control problems.

title: Introduction to Mechanical Vibrations
description: Free and forced vibrations in lumped-parameter systems with and without damping; vibrations in coupled systems; electromechanical analogs; use of energy conservation principles.

title: Environmental Physics & Society
description: Impact of humankind on the environment are discussed from the point of view of the physical sciences. Calculations based on physical principles will be made, and the resulting policy implications are considered.

title: Engineering Analysis
description: Solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations; approximation methods; solutions of ordinary differential equations; initial and boundary value problems; solutions of partial differential equations of Elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic types; Eigen value problems.

title: Science & Technology of Sustainable Power Generation
description: Focus on scientific understanding and development of power generation that is the basis of modern society. Concentration on power generation methods that are sustainable, in particular, discussion of the most recent innovations.

title: Professional Responsibilities of Engineers
description: Organization of the engineering profession; introduction to contracts, specifications, business law, patents, and liability; discussion of professional, ethical, societal, and political issues related to engineering.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

title: Technology Management
description: Management of the engineering and technology activity. Functions of design, planning, production, marketing, sales, and maintenance. Technological product life cycle. Research and development activity. Project planning and organization. Manufacturing issues. Case studies.

title: Special Topics in Engineering
description: Special topics in Engineering. Topics vary by instructor/quarter.

title: Introduction to Literature
description: Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments.

title: Writers' Workshop
description: Focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content for a writing task; to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

title: Introduction to Literature
description: Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.

title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Fiction
description: Elementary principles of writing fiction. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.

title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
description: Elementary principles of writing creative non-fiction. Work in prescribed literary forms (such as essay, meditation, biography, memoir, book review, documentary, or experimental non-fiction forms) and forms of students' choosing. No final examination.

title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Poetry
description: Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.

title: Literatures in English I: To 1700
description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and consumption.

title: Literatures in English II: 1700-1900
description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1700-1900. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, colonization, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. America, Britain, Ireland, Scotland, and India as important sites of English literary production and consumption.

title: Literatures in English III: 1900 to Present
description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1900-present. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. Formal experimentation. Modernism as transnational phenomenon.

title: Introductory Topics in Literature
description: Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.

title: Introductory Topics in Literature & Media
description: Study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and moving-image media.

title: Approaches to Reading
description: Close reading and interpretation of literature from a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches. Topics include traditional textual and historical approaches; new criticism; formalism; psychological criticism; feminism and gender; reader-response; materialist approaches. Frequent written assignments.

title: Introductory Topics in Drama
description: Close reading of, and topics relating to selected works of British and American drama from a range of historical periods.

title: Introductory Topics in Fiction
description: Close reading of, and topics relating to, British and American Fiction: short stories, novellas, novels.

title: Introductory Topics in Poetry
description: Topical study and close reading of selections from English and American poetry.

title: Hot Bars, Supreme Lyrics, & Rhymes for Days: Hip Hop as Poetry
description: Literary approaches to hip hop as poetry. Formal examination of rap lyrics in relation to technology, visual expression, dance, and knowledge production. Historical and cultural consideration of race, ethnicity, gender, urban culture, and politics.

title: Pop Culture Shakespeare
description: Critical approaches to the study of Shakespeare’s afterlife in contemporary American media. Focus on visual, audio, and kinesthetic modes of analysis and presentation. Relation of Shakespeare to contemporary society, politics, media, and economics.

title: Youth in Revolt
description: American literary and cultural representations of adolescence as a time of rebellious refusals and wild behaviors in relation to questions of gender and sexuality, psychological states, economic pressures, racial inequality, and methods of discipline and punishment.

title: Literature, Health, &  Medicine
description: Literary and cultural representations of health and medicine in relation to issues of race, gender, sexuality, and disability. Narratives and reading practices that provide complex accounts of the social determinants of health, contested understandings of illness, and critical perspectives on biomedicine.

title: Literary Animals
description: Literary exploration of animals as spectacles, symbols, scientific objects, human companions, and speaking subjects through animal fables and allegories, tales for children, poems, realist narratives, essays, and experimental fictions.

title: Speculative Fictions
description: Historical or thematic exploration of speculative genres such as science fiction, fantasy, utopia/dystopia, and/or horror. May include worldbuilding, intersections with scientific and other disciplinary knowledges, relation to social and political conditions.

title: Literatures of Climate Change
description: Readings in English-language climate change literature from around the world. Narratives of climate migration, adaptation, and geopolitical upheaval. Use of innovative literary forms and genres for representing the scale and impacts of global warming. Comparison of scientific and fictional scenarios.

title: Racial Imaginaries
description: Critical vocabularies and frameworks for studying the cultural construction of race as a signifier of human difference. Theories of racial formation in poetry, fiction, and other imaginative genres. Rhetorical and media strategies that present and/or obscure the material sources and institutional histories of race and racism.

title: Introduction to Games
description: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play. Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

title: Internship in English
description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

title: Student Facilitated Course
description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.

title: Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Special study for undergraduates.

title: Creative Writing: Fiction
description: Writing of fiction. No final examination.

title: Creative Writing Advanced Fiction
description: Development and evaluation of students' work in prose, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published novels and short stories. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.

title: Creative Writing Advanced Non-Fiction
description: Development and evaluation of students’ work in non-fiction, primarily in the workshop format. Reading and discussion of published works of non-fiction. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.

title: Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
description: Writing of non-fiction. No final examination.

title: Creative Writing: Poetry
description: Writing of poetry.

title: Creative Writing Advanced Poetry
description: Development and evaluation of students' work in poetry, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published works of poetry. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.

title: History of the English Language
description: History of the English language. Examination of the language as recorded from Old English to present-day English. Relationship of English to other languages; development of vocabulary, phonology, and grammatical patterns.

title: English Grammar
description: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.

title: English Grammar Practicum
description: Practice in teaching the principles of grammar to the kinds of audiences teachers encounter in California. Discussions with teachers who teach in these areas. Examination of pedagogical research on teaching grammar.

title: Freedom of Expression
description: Historical development of fundamental issues and contemporary controversies about freedom of expression, with emphasis on literary and artistic censorship.

title: Introduction to Literary Theory
description: Key theoretical terms, concepts, and thinkers from the Greeks to the modern era.

title: Introduction to Modern Literary & Critical Theory
description: History of literary criticism in the modern era, with emphasis on the ties with the past and the special problems presented by modern literary theory.

title: Topics in Medieval Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused intensive examination of selected topics in Medieval British literature.

title: Chaucer: Troilus & the "Minor" Poems
description: Development of the poet's artistry and ideas from his first work to his masterpiece, "Troilus and Criseyde"

title: Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales
description: Literary analysis of the complete "Canterbury Tales."  Courtly love, literary forms, medieval science and astrology, theology and dogma as they inform the reading of Chaucer's work.

title: Topics in 16th- & 17th-Century Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of the Renaissance.

title: Shakespeare
description: Historically, generically, or thematically focused study of Shakespeare's works.

title: Law & Literature
description: Historically, thematically, or generically focused study of the relationship between law and literature.

title: Milton
description: Selected major works, including Paradise Lost.

title: 18th-Century British Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of 18th-century English literature.

title: Topics in Irish Literature
description: Intensive study or treatment of special topics relating to the emergence, invention, and re-invention of Irish literature.

title: Food & Literature
description: English-language literatures of food from around the world. Literary cultures of food as they relate to broader cultural practices, ethnic and racial identities, place and diaspora. Literary genres and forms of food writing.

title: British Romantic Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of Romantic English literature.

title: 19th-Century British Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century English literature.

title: British Literature, 1900-1945
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.

title: British Literature, 1945 to Present
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present.

title: Topics in Global Literatures & Cultures
description: Historically or regionally focused study of world literatures in English (other than the national literatures of British Isles and the United States), particularly from post-colonial regions in Africa, the Caribbean, and Asia, and immigrant cultures in the English-speaking world.

title: Topics in Postcolonial Literatures & Cultures
description: Study of postcolonial literature of Anglophone colonies. Specific emphases may include literature from and about Anglophone India, the Caribbean, the Middle East, South Asia, Africa, and/or South America.

title: Topics in Diasporic Literatures & Migration
description: Study of literatures, histories, and cultures of one or more diasporic groups.

title: Early American Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature of the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: 19th-Century American Literature to the Civil War
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century American literature.

title: Post-Civil War American Literature
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of post-Civil War American literature.

title: Reading Race, Class, & Gender
description: Readings in literature and culture that present race, class, gender, sexuality, ability, and citizenship as inter-articulated signifiers of difference. Literature is contextualized alongside works of sociology, history, philosophy, and law. Inter-discursive nature of racial thought and policy, and on historical and rhetorical practices through which race acquires meaning.

title: American Literature 1900-1945
description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.

title: American Literature, 1945 to the Present
description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present.

title: Topics in Literature
description: Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not necessarily historically.

title: British Drama to 1800
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of English drama prior to 1800.

title: Drama from 1800 to the Present
description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British drama from 1800 to the present.

title: Topics in Drama
description: Historical or thematic study of drama.

title: The Graphic Novel
description: Thematically, historically, and formally focused study of the graphic novel genre. Contents may include any regional, national, or transnational group of graphic novels.

title: 18th-Century British Novel
description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 18th-century British novel, with particular emphasis on its evolution, including the epistolary novel, the picaresque novel, and the Gothic novel: Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Austen.

title: 19th-Century British Novel
description: Historically or thematically organized examination of 19th-century British novelists, with emphasis on the historical novel, the social novel, and novels by women: Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, Eliot, Hardy.

title: 20th-Century British Novel
description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 20th-century British novel, with emphasis on impressionism; the revolt against naturalism; the experimental novel; the anti-modernist reaction: Conrad, Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence, Drabble, Rhys.

title: The Short Story
description: The short story as a genre; its historical development, techniques, and formal character as a literary form. European as well as American writers.

title: Detective Fiction
description: Historically, formally, and thematically focused study of novels and short stories in the detective fiction genre.

title: The American Novel to 1900
description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the rise and development of the American novel from its beginnings; Hawthorne, Melville, Twain, James, and others.

title: The American Novel from 1900 to the Present
description: Historically or thematically organized examination of important American novelists from 1900 to the present: authors may include Willa Cather, Nathanael West, William Faulkner, Ralph Ellison, Zora Neale Hurston, Thomas Pynchon, Ishmael Reed, Maria Helena Viramontes, Rachel Kushner, and others.

title: Topics in the Novel
description: Examination of major novels arranged thematically. Topics might include Bildungsroman, stream-of-consciousness novel, Gothic novel, historical novel.

title: Film as Narrative
description: Study of modern film (1930 to present) as a storytelling medium.

title: Film Theory & Criticism
description: Film theory and criticism, with a study of ten major works of international film art.

title: Literary Study in the British Isles
description: Literary Study in the British Isles: On-site study of the literature, film, and/or performance of the British Isles.

title: Writing Science
description: Texts and writing practices in the production of scientific knowledge. Surveys the literary structure of scientific arguments; history of scientific genres; rhetoric and semiotics in scientific culture; graphical systems in the experimental laboratory; narratives of science, including science fiction.

title: Topics in Poetry
description: Intensive examination of various topics expressed in poetry from all periods of English and American literature.

title: Love & Desire in Contemporary American Poetry
description: Close reading of contemporary American poems on the theme of love and desire by poets of diverse ethnicities and of gay, lesbian, and heterosexual orientations.

title: 20th-Century African American Poetry
description: African American poetry in the 20th-century, including oral and literary traditions. Authors covered may include Gwendolyn Brooks, Countee Cullen, Robert Hayden, and Langston Hughes.

title: 20th-Century American Poetry
description: Historical Study of American poetry since 1900, with thematic and formal focus at the instructor's discretion.

title: Memoir & Life-Writing
description: English-language memoir and life-writing across various periods. Literary cultures of memoir as they relate to questions of identity, social situation, and broader ideologies of self and culture.

title: Narrative Game Design
description: Narrative game design. Character, dialogue, environmental storytelling, procedurally-generated text, play as narrative. Workshop, critique, and publish narrative and text-based games.

title: Game Studies Seminar
description: Theory and methods for researching games, play, media, and culture. Reading, writing, and discussion about playable media.

title: The Bible as Literature: The Old Testament
description: Selected readings from the Old Testament illustrating various literary forms. Emphasis on the Pentateuch, the Historical Books, and the Wisdom Books. May be taken independently ofENL 171B.

title: The Bible as Literature: Prophets & New Testament
description: Selected readings from the Old Testament prophets and the New Testament. May be taken independently ofENL 171A.

title: Video Games & Culture
description: Critical approaches to the study of video games, focusing on formal, historical, and cultural modes of analysis. History of software and hardware in North American and global contexts. Relations of games to society, politics, economics, media, etc.

title: Science Fiction
description: Literary modes and methods of science fiction. Representative texts, authors, and themes of the genre, e.g., time travel, alternative universes, and utopias. Relations of science fiction to science, philosophy, and culture.

title: Study of an Individual Author
description: In-depth study of an author's works; historical context; relation to predecessors and contemporaries; critical reception; influence.

title: Topics in Nations, Regions, & Other Cultural Geographies
description: Study of a local, regional, national, transnational, or other geographical literary formation (e.g., Global South; Literatures of the U.S./Mexico border; Literatures of the Pacific; Indigenous North American literature) centering underrepresented racial and/or ethnic perspectives.

title: Topics in Comparative Racial & Ethnic Literary Studies
description: Writings by Black, Indigenous, and/or People-of-Color authors responding to specific American contexts of racialization such as slavery, imperial warfare, international and internal migration, naturalization law, religion, mass incarceration, and environmental injustice.

title: Children's Literature
description: Historical backgrounds and development of types of children's literature, folklore and oral tradition, levels of interest, criticism and evaluation, illustration and bibliography.

title: African American Literature to 1900
description: African American literature from the colonial period to 1900. Particular attention to the rapid development of the African American literary culture from a primarily oral tradition to various literary genres, including the slave narrative.

title: African American Literature 1900-Present
description: Major African American writers in the context of cultural history from 1900 to the present. Writers may include Richard Wright, Ann Petry, James Baldwin, Ralph Ellison, Paule Marshall, Toni Morrison, Alice Walker, Clarence Major.

title: Literature of California
description: Focus is on the diverse contributions to the rise of California literature from the 19th century to today. Reading of poetry, fiction, and essays. Includes Native American, Latino/a, and other Californian writers.

title: Young Adult Literature
description: Theoretical, critical, and literary issues informing the study and teaching of American young adult literature.

title: Literature & the Environment
description: Historical and/or thematic survey of topics in writing about the environment.

title: Literature by Women Before 1800
description: Women's Writing in English before 1800; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.

title: Literature by Women from 1800-1900
description: Women's Writing in English from 1800 to 1900; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.

title: Literature by Women after 1900
description: Women's Writing in English after 1900; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.

title: Literature, Sexuality, & Gender
description: Historically or thematically focused intensive examinations of gender and sexuality in British and American literature.

title: Topics in Literature & Media
description: Group study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and film or other moving-image media.

title: Topics in Literary & Critical Theory
description: Intensive examination of theories addressing a particular problem, topic, or question.

title: Seminar in Literary Studies
description: Intensive, focused study of literature at an advanced level. May be organized by topic, author, period, movement, or genre. High participation.

title: Internship in English
description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. A maximum of 4 units is allowed toward the major in English.

title: Seminar for Honors Students
description: Preparation for writing an honors thesis inENL 195H. High level of participation expected.

title: Honors Thesis
description: Preparation of a thesis, under the supervision of an instructor. Students satisfying requirements for the general major or the teaching emphasis write on a scholarly or critical subject; creative writing students submit a volume of poems or fiction.

title: Tutoring in English
description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups designed to develop reading and writing skills and affiliated with one of the university's regular courses.

title: Community Tutoring in English
description: Field experience, with individuals or in classroom in instruction of English language, literature, and composition. Does not fulfill requirement for major.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

title: Student Facilitated Course
description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for upper division students.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Group study closely tied to the texts and periods studied in ENL 163S. Investigations of historical sites, museums, galleries, and performances.

title: Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

title: Student Facilitated Course Development
description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will offer under 098F/198F.

title: Student Facilitated Teaching
description: STU FAC. Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.

title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in English
description: Introduction to literary scholarship with special attention to the elements of professionalism and to different modes of literary investigation.

title: Anglo-Saxon Language & Culture
description: The language and culture of Anglo-Saxon England; readings in Old English prose and poetry.

title: Beowulf
description: A study of the poem and the Heroic Age of Germanic literature.

title: Middle English
description: Study of the phonology, morphology, syntax, and lexicon between 1100 and 1500 with investigation of the regional dialects; pertinent facts on both the internal and external linguistic history; intensive reading of texts.

title: Readings in English & American Literature
description: Content varies according to specialty of instructor.

title: Topics in Irish Literature
description: Varied topics, including the 19th-century novel, contemporary Irish poetry, rise of the drama, or a study of a major author.

title: Study of a Major Writer
description: Artistic development of one major writer and his intellectual and literary milieu.

title: Problems in English Literature
description: Selected issues in the current study and critical assessment of a limited period or topic in English literature.

title: Problems in American Literature
description: Selected topics for intensive investigation.

title: Dramatic Literature
description: Historical introduction to dramatic theory; the genres of tragedy, comedy, and tragicomedy.

title: Theory of Fiction
description: Theories of fiction as they relate to the professional writer's practice of the craft. For students in the Creative Writing Program.

title: Seminar for Writers
description: Varied topics in the study of literature and literary culture craft and poetics from the perspective of the writer/practitioner.

title: Special Topics in Literary Theory
description: Advanced topics in literary theory and criticism. Preparation and evaluation of research paper.

title: Medieval Literature
description: Studies of Medieval literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: 16th-Century Literature
description: Studies in 16th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Shakespeare
description: Studies in Shakespeare. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: 17th-Century Literature
description: Studies in 17th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: 18th-Century Literature
description: Studies in 18th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Romantic Literature
description: Studies in Romantic literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Victorian Literature
description: Studies in Victorian literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: 20th-Century British Literature
description: Studies in 20th-century British literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Early American Literature
description: Studies in Early American literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: American Literature: 1800 to the Civil War
description: Studies in American literature from 1800 to Civil War. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: American Literature: Civil War to 1914
description: Studies in American literature from the Civil War to 1914. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: American Literature after 1914
description: Studies in American literature after 1914. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Studies in Modern British & American Literature
description: Studies in modern British and American literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Studies in Contemporary World Literature
description: Emerging global, international or transnational techniques, theories, and individual works of contemporary world prose or poetry. Discussion, seminar reports, research papers.

title: Proseminar in Research Practices
description: Study of various practical and technical skills needed to perform research in literary studies. Materials to be selected by the instructor. Evaluation based on student projects that involve hands-on application of skills taught in the proseminar.

title: Seminar in Research Practices
description: Study of various practical and technical skills needed to perform research in literary studies. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Evaluation based on student projects that involve hands-on application of skills taught in the seminar.

title: Literature by Women
description: Studies in literature by women and the theoretical approaches to literature by women. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Topics in Literature & Media
description: Study of a topic centered on film or other moving-image media. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

title: Prospectus Workshop
description: Training in writing the dissertation prospectus. Participation in group discussions of preparatory assignments and final proposal.

title: Article Writing Workshop
description: Training in preparing an article for publication. Participation in group discussions of article drafts.

title: Creative Writing: Special Topic
description: Writing that falls outside the generic confines of traditional genres (fiction, poetry, and nonfiction) or traditional workshop formats. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.

title: Creative Writing: Fiction
description: Writing of prose fiction. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.

title: Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
description: Writing of literary non-fiction, with emphasis on autobiography, biography, memoir, the occasional or nature essay, or other non-fiction prose narratives.

title: Creative Writing: Poetry
description: Writing of poetry. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

title: Individual Study
description: Individual study.

title: Special Study for the Doctoral Dissertation
description: Special study for the doctoral dissertation.

title: Teaching Creative Writing
description: Designed for new instructors ofENL 005ForENL 005P; discussion of ways to facilitate creative writing workshops and to respond to student manuscripts.

title: Teaching Literature & Composition
description: Designed for new instructors ofENL 003or the equivalent courses; discussion of problems related to teaching literature and composition to lower division students.

title: Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Teaching assistant training.

title: Art, Science & the World of Insects
description: Fusion of entomology and art to create an appreciation of insect biology, ecology, interactions with humans and importance in human culture. Multidisciplinary approaches in education and career paths in entomology and art will be highlighted.

title: Biodiversity
description: Introduction to nature, scope and geographical distribution of biodiversity (diversity of life, with emphasis on plants and animals, especially insects). Humans and biodiversity; domestication, aesthetics, ethics and valuation. Species richness and "success." Biodiversity through time; monitoring, evaluation and conservation. Biomes-global, continental and Californian.

title: Natural History of Insects
description: Introduction to the insects detailing their great variety, structures and functions, habits, and their significance in relation to plants and animals including man. Designed for students not specializing in entomology.

title: Special Topics in Entomology
description: Freshman seminar course for indepth examination of a special topic within the subject area.

title: Internship
description: Work-learn experience on and off campus in all subject areas offered by the department, supervised by a member of the faculty.

title: Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Special study for undergraduates.

title: General Entomology
description: Biology, anatomy, physiology, development, classification, ecology and relation of insects to human welfare.

title: General Entomology Laboratory
description: Anatomy, development, population ecology, methods of collecting, classification and identification of insects of all orders and of major families.

title: Functional Insect Morphology
description: Study of the basic external and internal structures, organs and tissues of insects, with emphasis on functional systems. Functional anatomy, histology and fine structures of important organs and tissues will be discussed.

title: Insect Physiology
